description: From Middle English circuler, circuleer, circulere, from Old French circulier, from Late Latin circularis, from Latin circulus, diminutive of circus (“ring”).

adjectives.description: circular (comparative more circular, superlative most circular)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to a circle.
In the shape of, or moving in a circle.
Referring back to itself, so as to prevent computation or comprehension; infinitely recursive.
examples: Your dictionary defines "brave" as "courageous", and "courageous" as "brave". That's a circular definition.
a circular formula in a spreadsheet
I changed the definition of "sex" from "to have sex" to "to have sexual intercourse";  a dictionary definition must never be circular; using the word being defined to define itself.

entries.meaning: Distributed to a large number of persons.

examples: A man so absolute and circular / In all those wished-for rarities that may take / A virgin captive.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Adhering to a fixed circle of legends; cyclic; hence, mean; inferior.
examples: Had Virgil been a circular poet, and closely adhered to history, how could the Romans have had Dido?

entries.meaning: Synonym of flyer: a printed advertisement, directive, or notice intended for mass circulation.
(dated) A sleeveless cloak cut from a circular pattern.
A shuttle bus with a circular route.

verbs.description: circular (third-person singular simple present circulars, present participle circularing, simple past and past participle circulared)

entries.meaning: To distribute circulars to or at.
To extend in a circular direction.
